The History of Italian Immigrants in the United States

Creator: Hine, Lewis Wickes

Title: The Arnao family of berry pickers in the fields of Truitt's farm. This is an Italian family coming from Phildelphia and now ready to go to Carmel, N.J. to continue picking. The family consists of: 1 child 3 years of age, 1 child 6 years of age, 2 children 7 years of age, 1 child 9 years of age, 1 child 10 years of age, 1 child 11 years of age. All of whom pick. Location: Cannon, Delaware.

Date: 1910 May

Format: Photograph

Institution: National Child Labor Committee collection

Link: https://www.loc.gov/item/2018675928/

Italians have a rich history in the United States, by 1920 over 4 million Italians migrated to the United States. Most of these Italians landed on Ellis Island, a small island outside of NYC. Like many other immigrants who migrated to the United States, Italians were driven to leave their country due to years of political chaos, poverty and violence. By the 20th century in the United States, Italians who were already living here began expanding across the nation. As Italians started moving to different parts of the country, they started finding themselves in a variety of different jobs and opportunities. In the Appalachian Mountains and the mountain West, many Italians worked in the mines and the pits excavating for coal and ore. Many Italians also found work on farms and ranches in the northeast, the south and California. The photo above is an Italian family picking berries in Delaware in 1910.
